Add a Service to a Domain

Source: vignettes/articles/add_domain_service.Rmd
add_domain_service.Rmd
Don't confuse a Domain Service with an Application Service. If you are looking for a component that enables a remote client to interact with your system, then you need an Application Service, not a Domain Service.
Application Services serve clients by orchestrating Domain Services. Domain Services are not aware and have no knowledge of any Application Service.

What does add_domain_service do?

Given a Domain Service name, and its domain name,

When add_domain_service is called

add_domain_service(name = 'Registry', domain = 'Pizza Ordering')

Then the function:

  • Generates boilerplate code for the Domain Service and saves it at R/pizza_ordering-service-Registry.R;
  • Generates a unit-test for the Domain Service and saves it at tests/testthat/test-pizza_ordering-service-Registry.R; and
  • Opens the files (only in interactive mode).
You don't need to remember the naming style for the different DDD components. Instead, ddd takes care of naming style for all domain objects. This way DDD file names, classes and functions are congruent with each other.

What are the main components of a Domain Service?

The boilerplate code for the Registry Domain Service class produced by add_domain_service looks like this:

R/pizza_ordering-service-Registry.R

#' @title Registry Domain Service
#' @family Pizza Ordering
#' @noRd
Registry <- R6::R6Class("Registry", inherit = AbstractDomainService, lock_objects = FALSE, cloneable = FALSE)

# Public Methods ----------------------------------------------------------
Registry$set("public", "command", function(
    entity = DummyEntity$new(uid = NULL),
    value_object = DummyValueObject()
){
    stopifnot(any(class(entity) %in% "Entity"))
    stopifnot(any(class(value_object) %in% "data.frame"))

    tryCatch({
        # TODO: Write code that uses uow interface
        self$uow$commit()
    },
    error = function(e){
        # TODO: Raise event handler
        self$uow$rollback()
    })

    invisible(self)
})

Registry$set("public", "query", function(uid = character(0)){
    stopifnot(is.character(uid))

    entity <- tryCatch({
        # TODO: Write code that uses uow interface
        entity <- NULL
        if(is.null(entity)) stop("entity uid doen't exist") else entity
    },
    error = function(e){
        # TODO: Raise event handler
        return(NULL)
    })

    return(entity)
})

Notice the two public methods created by add_domain_service:

  1. command is a boilerplate for a service that updates data
  2. query is a boilerplate for a service that returns data

Domain Services are stateless by design. That means that once a service is done serving, the environment in which it had lived is deleted. If you need to track information from call to call, you would have to use a persistent storage.

There are several common implementation of a persistent storage.

The boilerplate code for the Registry Domain Service unit-test produced by add_domain_service looks like this:

tests/testthat/test-pizza_ordering-service-Registry.R

context('unit test for domain-service Registry')

# Setup -------------------------------------------------------------------
testthat::setup({
    assign("test_env", testthat::test_env(), envir = parent.frame())
})

# Tests -------------------------------------------------------------------
test_that("instantiate a Registry Domain Service", {
    attach(test_env)
    expect_is(domain_service <- Registry$new(), "DomainService")
    test_env$domain_service <- domain_service
})

test_that("calling Registry$command performs an action", {
    attach(test_env)
    expect_is(domain_service$command(), "DomainService")
})

test_that("calling Registry$query returns the desired results", {
    attach(test_env)
    expect_null(domain_service$query(uid = character(0)))
})

# Cleanup -----------------------------------------------------------------
testthat::teardown(rm(domain_service, envir = test_env))
